[[type:skills]]
[[type:tools]]

# Horizon scanning

![](data:image/png;base64,)

## Overview
Horizon scanning is a strategic approach used to identify and analyze early signs of potential future developments, trends, threats, and opportunities.

## Purpose
The purpose of horizon scanning is to enable organizations to anticipate changes, adapt strategies, and prepare for various possible outcomes by examining information from a broad range of sources.

## How it works
Horizon scanning involves collecting signals of change from various sources, categorizing them, interpreting their implications, and identifying gaps or needed adjustments in current strategies. This process can be done through online forms, Excel, shared online drives, or advanced data visualization tools.

## Requirements
To effectively use horizon scanning, participants need to identify a clear scope for the exercise, have basic digital literacy, collect inputs from a diverse group of signal scanners, and engage actively throughout the activity.

## Reflections
When using horizon scanning, it is essential to keep in mind that this tool requires extended time periods to allow participants to consult with new sources and share further information on identified signals.

## Related methods (if any)
Horizon scanning is often used in conjunction with other methods such as Foresight, Future Analysis, Collective Intelligence, data collection, System Thinking, and explore.

## License
The license for horizon scanning is not specified, but it can be considered a free or open tool, as it does not require any specific software or proprietary materials.

## Examples
Horizon scanning has been used in various contexts, including the future of work consultations, where it was employed to identify early signs of emerging trends and technologies related to the digital revolution.
